title: Stability and Testability: Groups and Codes
descriptions:
Abstract:

The proposed project, "Stability and Testability: Groups and Codes," seeks to bridge the gap between algebra, group theory, and computer science by exploring a unified approach to the concepts of stability and testability. It delves into fundamental questions such as the relationship between almost solutions and exact solutions, the sofic and hyperlinear nature of all groups, and the existence of high-quality locally testable codes.

Central to the research are problems including the commutativity of unitary matrices within small deformations, the characterization of almost homomorphisms between groups as near to true homomorphisms, and the broader application of these concepts within group theory and error-correcting codes. The work will draw upon key concepts such as almost commutation, group stability, and property testing, while also considering specific cases like the actions of group \(Z \times Z\) on the unitary group \(Un(C)\).

The project aims to develop innovative methods for studying these phenomena, as well as to provide significant contributions to the "holy grail" problems of the field. The approach is informed by related concepts and structures, including high-dimensional expanders, Ramanujan complexes, and lattices in p-adic simple groups, which may offer new insights and tools.

The team will build upon the foundational work of prominent mathematicians such as Gromov and Connes, aiming to clarify the intricate connections between group theory and the theory of error-correcting codes. By addressing these foundational questions and developing a cohesive framework for group stability and code testability, the project sets the stage for substantial theoretical advancements with potential implications in various applications within computer science and mathematics.

Abstract:

The project "Stability and Testability: Groups and Codes" aims to integrate approaches from Algebra, Group Theory, and Computer Science to address foundational questions concerning the nature of stability and testability within mathematical structures and error-correcting codes. Focused on key concerns in the field such as the conditions under which unitary matrices that almost commute could be considered small deformations of commuting matrices, and whether every near homomorphism is a minor modification of a true homomorphism, this research endeavors to bridge theoretical gaps and push forward the understanding of group behavior.

Our team will explore specific cases, such as the behavior of the group Z x Z and its relationship with the unitary group Un(C), to develop generalized methods that can be applied to broader classes of problems. We will consider the conjectures asking whether all groups are sofic or hyperlinear, and investigate the existence of high-quality locally testable codes, which have profound implications in both theoretical and applied computer science.

The ideas of stability and testability serve as the project's core, with an emphasis on understanding almost solutions in relation to exact solutions. This connects with the broader mathematical landscape, including areas such as High Dimensional Expanders, Ramanujan Complexes, and Lattices in p-adic Simple Groups. By referencing the work of luminaries like Gromov and Connes, we will build on a robust theoretical foundation to tackle the so-called "holy grail" problems within these domains.

This project is poised to make significant contributions to our understanding of group stability, property testing, and coding theory, by developing new methods and addressing long-standing open questions. It aims to unify perspectives from different fields to solve problems that are central to both theoretical exploration and practical applications.

Abstract:

The "Stability and Testability: Groups and Codes" project seeks to investigate the foundational questions at the intersection of Algebra, Group Theory, and Computer Science. This research project will explore several profound problems, including the examination of whether almost solutions in the context of unitary matrices and group homomorphisms can be considered as small deformations of exact solutions. Key questions such as "Are all groups sofic or hyperlinear?" and "Are there effective locally testable codes?" will be addressed, leveraging the concepts of stability and testability within both group theory and error-correcting codes.

The project has several specific examples to guide the investigation, such as exploring whether two unitary matrices, which almost commute, are a small deformation away from matrices that do commute exactly. Another example investigates the nature of almost homomorphisms from a group D to a topological group G, questioning if they are close to being true homomorphisms.

The research will incorporate related concepts such as high-dimensional expanders, Ramanujan complexes, and actions on associated buildings, which are essential in understanding the broader implications of the study in the field of algebraic topology and geometric group theory.

The objectives are twofold: to develop innovative methods to study stability and testability in these areas and to tackle the holy grail problems that are central to our understanding of group theory and computer science. This project is expected to provide significant contributions to the fields of study by unifying perspectives on group theoretic problems and the theory of error-correcting codes, with potential applications spanning both theoretical and practical domains.

Through this proposal, we aim to advance the field by building upon the work of renowned mathematicians such as Gromov and Connes, and by exploring new frontiers in the study of sofic and hyperlinear groups, as well as the construction and analysis of locally testable codes. The outcomes of this research will have far-reaching implications for the mathematical community, potentially unlocking new understandings of algebraic structures and computational complexity.

Abstract:

The proposed research project, "Stability and Testability: Groups and Codes," seeks to forge a groundbreaking synthesis between the fields of Algebra, Group Theory, and Computer Science. The primary focus is on the exploration of stability and testability within group theory and error-correcting codes, two areas that have seen considerable independent interest but whose interconnections have not yet been fully realized.

With key questions addressing whether 'almost solutions' can be considered small deformations of 'exact solutions', the project examines specific cases such as unitary matrices that almost commute and almost homomorphisms from discrete groups to topological groups, with an eye towards providing definitive answers to whether all groups are sofic or hyperlinear, and whether there exist high-quality locally testable codes.

The research is particularly significant due to its potential to answer some of the most challenging and fundamental problems in the associated fields, often referred to as the 'holy grail' problems. For instance, it will consider whether two unitary matrices that almost commute are indeed slight deformations of matrices that truly commute, or if every almost homomorphism is a small deformation of a true homomorphism.

In pursuing these questions, the project will draw on related concepts such as Group Stability, Property Testing, High Dimensional Expanders, Ramanujan Complexes, and the actions on associated buildings. The team will develop innovative methods to study these problems, leveraging the expertise of leading researchers and the legacy of foundational work by figures such as Gromov and Connes.

By unifying problems in group theory and error-correcting codes under the overarching themes of stability and testability, this research holds promise for significant advances in understanding the structure and capabilities of both mathematical groups and computational systems. The outcomes of this project are expected to forge new pathways in mathematical research and have profound implications for computational applications, enhancing the robustness and efficiency of algorithms and codes in computer science.
